instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00928: What is 820-00928? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Recognizing SSD
threads.message: So I have an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> that is not recognizing the SSD. The customer states they were just working and it stopped working. The computer turns on but has a flashing ? folder. I took out the board and do not see any signs of corrosion or broken probe points. Any Ideas where to look?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Recognizing SSD
threads.message:
First, be sure J9600 metal plate is in place and makes good contacts.
Boot USB macOS and check if SSD is at least detected in Disk Uyility.

You can also check all the power rails related with SSD.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Recognizing SSD
threads.message: Ok, Cover on J9600 is in place and the screws are tight and when I boot to external, disk utility does not see the internal SSD. Will have to figure out what SSD rails to check.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Recognizing SSD
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Recognizing SSD
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Recognizing SSD
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Recognizing SSD
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Recognizing SSD
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Recognizing SSD
threads.message: Spent 30 min going through every voltage on that page, checked every capacitor, resistor and trace. Didn't see anything out of the ordinary.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Recognizing SSD
threads.message:
Heat SSD NANDs and controller, just for test.
It could be CPU issue also...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Recognizing SSD
threads.message: What do you mean heat? Reflow, or just warm them up? They all have that underfill crap around them.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Recognizing SSD
threads.message: oh my god!!!! I heated the nand and it freaking worked!!!!!!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Recognizing SSD
threads.message: I can see the login screen but that is it

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Recognizing SSD
threads.message: so it is not fully working but we are onto something

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Recognizing SSD
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Recognizing SSD
threads.message: as soon as it cools off back to blinking ? folder

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Recognizing SSD
threads.message:
So there can be internal problem with NAND chips; or something else connected together; SSD controller, CPU...

Very risky to reflow/reball these underfilled chips.
You should say to the client before heat again the chips; board can get dead completely.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00928</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Recognizing SSD
threads.message: Thank you for your reply.  I ended up giving back to client as is was not worth the risk. They said they will send to Apple. Appreciate the help
